answers.answer: Without a complete history, physical exam, lab review and medication list, I can’t give you an exact diagnosis or treatment plan.  We start to worry about liver function tests, one of which is ALT, when they are three times the upper limit of normal, which yours is nowhere near.  Also, if you have been on Soriatane for 14 years, it is unlikely that it is causing an acute problem now.  You say you are overweight and sometimes a fatty liver can cause a bump in the liver enzymes.  Have you been tested for Hepatitis C?The number I would focus on more is your HgbA1C at 15.7.  You want it to go below 7.0. The HgbA1C represents your sugar control in the last 2-3 months.  The UKPDS study demonstrated for every percentage point decrease in HgbA1C (e.g., 9 to 8%), there was a 35% reduction in the risk of complications from retinopathy (which can lead to blindness) and nephropathy (which can lead to kidney failure).My advice would be to focus on getting your weight down to the normal range (BMI 18-24) and you may, more than likely, see all your “numbers” heading toward normal.  Best thing is to start slow by focusing on losing the first 5-10 lbs.

question: Turning 55 in a few days. New to Kaiser. Have Psoriasis, HBP, overweight, lack exercise, Type II diabetes, no alcohol except Nyquil (recent flu).Cholest, AST, Creatinine, CBC all in range.HBA1c high at 157Have been on Soriatane for 14 years.Only out of range is: ALT @ 46. Should I be worried about this? Could this be Soiratane caused? What direction should I go?Thank you!Jim
title: Psoriasis and liver (HIGH ALT of 46)
